thread.title: 9 Arrests Made in Wrigleyville Wednesday: Police
thread.title_full: 9 Arrests Made in Wrigleyville Wednesday: Police

author: NATALIE MARTINEZ
title: 9 Arrests Made in Wrigleyville Wednesday: Police
text:
Close Embed this video <script type="text/javascript" charset="UTF-8" src="http://www.nbcchicago.com/portableplayer/?cmsID=331181481&videoID=MkSZ9aq1nsPP&origin=nbcchicago.com&sec=news&subsec=sports&width=600&height=360"></script> More videos (1 of 9) « » NBC 5's Natalie Martinez reports as Cubs fans in Wrigleyville enjoy their team's win against the Pirates. (Published Wednesday, Oct. 7, 2015) Cubs fans were excited about the team's win against the Pirates Wednesday -- but a few people ended the night in handcuffs. Chicago police said nine people were arrested for misdemeanor crimes n Wrigleyville. Another 12 received tickets. Arrieta on Being Hit by Pitch: 'I Anticipated That' Some fans feared that celebrations might get out of hand. "I hope we can have as much fun as we can without people being stupid," said Cubs fan, Whitney Smith. PHOTOS: Cubs Fans Celebrate in Wrigleyville Many people were seen cheering underneath the Wrigley Field marquee sign at the corner of Addison and Clark. On Monday, some Wrigleyville business owners met with fire and police on Monday to lay out a plan ahead of the celebrations. Cubs Win Wild Card Game 4-0 Over Pirates Alderman Tom Tunney said Tuesday that bars and restaurants in the Wrigleyville area will have additional security and will use plastic cups instead of glass. Police said in a statement that they "have implemented enhancements to the deployment and without going into specific numbers, we're prepared from a resource perspective to keep everyone safe to celebrate a Cubs win." Wrigleyville Businesses on Alert Ahead of Wild Card Game Even though the Chicago Cubs will fight to win the National League Wild Card Game in Pittsburgh Wednesday, officials in the team's hometown neighborhood are preparing for the many fans that will flock to watch the game. NBC 5's Natalie Martinez reports. (Published Tuesday, Oct. 6, 2015) The security precautions came after hundreds of Chicago Blackhawks fans took to the streets to celebrate the team’s Stanley Cup victory in 2013, breaking down police barricades , setting off fireworks and shattering storefronts. Nearly two dozen people were arrested in the celebration. Published at 1:56 AM CDT on Oct 8, 2015
